instances.explanation: Using legal terms ('case,' 'contends in judgment'), the verse metaphorically casts God’s dealings with the nations as a courtroom lawsuit.

instances.english_text: He delivers the wicked to the sword
target: the execution of the wicked through violent means
their being killed in war or judgment
vehicle: a sword as the instrument of execution
ground: the sword concretely symbolizes the act of killing and warfare
giving someone to the sword means subjecting them to lethal violence
instrument-for-action relation
posture: depicts God as handing over the wicked to deserved death
clarifies the seriousness of their condemnation
retributive/solemn
instances.explanation: The 'sword' is a standard metonymy for lethal judgment in war or execution; God giving them to the sword means He consigns them to violent death.

deliberation: Two figurative moves: 'Disaster goes forth from nation to nation' personifies 'disaster' as an agent that travels; 'a great storm is stirred up from the remotest parts of the earth' uses storm imagery as a metaphor for sweeping judgment or invading forces.

instances.english_text: Disaster goes forth from nation to nation
target: the spread of conflict and calamity across nations
vehicle: an agent ('evil/disaster') that sets out and travels
something moving from one place to another
ground: both a traveling agent and the spread of disaster move from place to place
suggests contagion and inevitability
propagation/directionality
posture: portrays judgment as an active force unleashed by God
emphasizes its dynamic, spreading character
ominous
instances.explanation: The noun 'evil/disaster' is personified as if it can 'go out' and move between nations, highlighting the active, spreading nature of the calamity.

instances.english_text: A great storm is unleashed from the remotest parts of earth
target: the massive upheaval of international judgment/invasion
vehicle: a great storm arising from the earth’s extremities
ground: both a storm and large-scale judgment are overwhelming, uncontrollable, and destructive
they sweep across regions from afar
force, unpredictability, scope
posture: communicates the terror and uncontrollable nature of the coming events
underscores that the source is beyond human control ('remotest parts')
threatening/awesome
instances.explanation: The 'great storm' metaphor captures the violence and breadth of God’s judgment, with hyperbolic 'remotest parts of earth' heightening its ominous origin.

deliberation: Two main figures: 'from one end of the earth to the other' hyperbolically universalizes the carnage; 'they shall become dung upon the face of the earth' is an explicit simile/metaphor of corpses like manure, stressing contempt and pollution.

instances.english_text: from one end of the earth to the other

vehicle: the conceptual 'ends' or extremities of the earth

stresses comprehensiveness rather than cartographic detail
totality
posture: underscores the enormity of divine judgment
aims to produce fear and sobriety
universalizing/threatening
instances.explanation: The idiom 'from end to end of the earth' hyperbolically asserts the widespread nature of the slaughter.

instances.english_text: they shall become dung upon the face of the earth
target: the unburied corpses of those slain by the LORD
vehicle: excrement that defiles and is trodden underfoot
ground: both dung and unburied corpses are despised, polluting, and left exposed
suggests utter contempt and lack of honor
defilement and worthlessness
posture: deliberately degrades the wicked, showing the depth of their disgrace
warns hearers against the path that leads to such an end
shocking/morally charged
instances.explanation: Corpses left unburied are likened to dung on the ground, a strong simile/metaphor expressing contempt and ritual defilement.

deliberation: Two distinct figures: (1) 'shepherds' and 'lords of the flock' are metaphors for rulers/leaders, extended by 'your slaughter' imagery; (2) 'you shall fall like a precious vessel' is a simile comparing their downfall to the shattering of a valued object.

instances.hebrew_text: הֵילִילוּ הָרֹעִים ... אַדִּירֵי הַצֹּאן כִּי־מָלְאוּ יְמֵיכֶם לִטְבֹחַ
instances.english_text: Howl, you shepherds, and yell, you lords of the flock! For the day of your slaughter draws near
target: the political and religious leaders of the people
vehicle: shepherds and lords of a flock facing slaughter-time
pastoral scene of animals and their keepers
ground: leaders care for people as shepherds for sheep, and judgment makes them like animals led to slaughter
high-status figures are reduced to vulnerable flock
care, responsibility, and vulnerability
posture: turns the usual shepherd-care image into one of impending doom for the shepherds themselves
condemns leaders for failure and announces their fate
critical/judicial
instances.explanation: Leaders are metaphorically called 'shepherds' and 'lords of the flock'; the reference to their 'slaughter' turns the pastoral image into one of their own destruction.

instances.english_text: and you shall fall like a precious vessel

fragility despite apparent value

undercuts their self-importance with an image of fragility
warning/humbling
instances.explanation: An explicit simile likens the leaders’ fall to that of a precious vessel that shatters when it falls, highlighting their vulnerability and irreversible ruin.

deliberation: Continues the shepherd-leader metaphor: 'flight shall fail the shepherds, and escape, the lords of the flock' applies the pastoral titles to rulers; the language of flight and escape is literal in context.

instances.hebrew_text: וְאָבַד מָנוֹס מִן־הָרֹעִים וּפְלֵיטָה מֵאַדִּירֵי הַצֹּאן
instances.english_text: Flight shall fail the shepherds, and escape, the lords of the flock

shared vulnerability and responsibility

reinforces inevitability of judgment on the elite
forensic/leveling
instances.explanation: Rulers are again depicted as 'shepherds' and 'lords of the flock'; this metaphor underscores that they cannot run from the devastation overtaking their people.

deliberation: Still within the shepherd-leader complex: the 'outcry of the shepherds' and 'howls of the lords of the flock' refer to leaders’ cries; 'ravaging their pasture' uses pasture as metaphor for the realm/people under their care.

instances.hebrew_text: קוֹל צַעֲקַת הָרֹעִים וִילְלַת אַדִּירֵי הַצֹּאן כִּי־שֹׁדֵד יְהוָה אֶת־מַרְעִיתָם
instances.english_text: Hark, the outcry of the shepherds, and the howls of the lords of the flock! For the LORD is ravaging their pasture

interdependence of leader, flock, and land

evokes pathos but also just deserts
forensic and plaintive
instances.explanation: The shepherd and pasture imagery metaphorically represents rulers and their territories/people, with God 'ravaging their pasture' as judgment.

deliberation: The 'peaceful meadows' being destroyed continues the pasture metaphor for secure settlements or conditions; the meadows stand for the communities’ state of peace that will be ended by YHWH’s wrath.

instances.hebrew_text: וְנָדַמּוּ נְאוֹת הַשָּׁלוֹם מִפְּנֵי חֲרוֹן אַף־יְהוָה

peaceful flourishing

instances.explanation: The 'peaceful meadows' are a metaphor and metonymy for the settled, prosperous state of the people, which will be silenced by God’s angry judgment.

deliberation: Key figure: 'Like a young lion he has left his lair'—a simile comparing God (or the invading agent of His wrath) to a lion emerging to ravage; the ensuing 'their land has become a desolation because of his fierce anger' is intense but conceptually straightforward.

sudden, powerful aggression

ominous/majestic
instances.explanation: An explicit simile likens God’s going forth in wrath to a lion leaving its lair to pounce, emphasizing the terrifying and predatory nature of the judgment.
